subtitles.subtitle_text: The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me.
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Chosokabe! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Date! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Hojo! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Hattori! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me.
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Ikko - Ikki! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Mori! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Oda! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Shimazu! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Takeda! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Tokugawa! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
The wind has changed. Now, we fly like dragons! No longer will I bow to lesser men. All bow to me!
But our enemies still march. So what? Victory is within my grasp!
All will fear the Uesugi! All will fear me! For I am shogun!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
It is dangerous to be the tallest tree, for that is where the axe strikes first.
We are victims of conspiracy!
I am called an enemy of the state! We must have vigilance! We must prepare for war!
A season for change: Leaves playfully mock the wind. Autumn has come.
Shivering beauty Raises my spirit higher: The herald of spring.
Fields of autumn gold. Hard work reflects in water. The harvest gathered.
When will spring arrive? In the grip of cold white death, The earth is smothered.
After the battle of Sekigahara the Tokugawa Shogunate dominated Japan.
Those who fought Tokugawa Ieyasu became the “Tozama”, the outsiders.
Disgraced, the Tozama daimyo and their descendants were forever excluded from positions of power.
Instead, they looked abroad, prospering through commerce with China and the West.
Threatened by the newly-wealthy Tozama, Tokugawa Iemitsu, grandson of Ieyasu, closed the ports of Japan, banning all foreign trade.
For over 200 years Japan remained isolated. With no enemies, the power of the Shogunate waned.
Then, in 1853, a fleet of American warships forced open the ports of Japan. The Shogun was humiliated.
Revolutionary ideas and machines from the West began to flood the country.
With the Shogun's position weakened, his enemies begin to circle.
The Tozama daimyo, even the Emperor himself, see the chance to bring down the Tokugawa and rule Japan.
Takamori and his Imperial allies succeeded in extinguishing the last embers of Tokugawa support on the 17th May 1869.
A new government was formed, with the Emperor Meiji as its head.
The Meiji government made sweeping reforms.
The samurai lost their privileges in society, and the power and domains of the daimyo were abolished.
Japan abandoned its policy of international isolation and rapidly became a modern nation.
However, many traditionalists were resentful, and they had a powerful figurehead to rally around.
Eight years after the Meiji restoration, the great samurai Saigo Takamori rebelled.
Initially successful, the rebels were hopelessly outnumbered and were soon pushed back to Satsuma.
On a hillside with his few remaining men, Takamori made his final stand. Surrounded by thousands of government troops, he died a warrior’s death.
Saigo Takamori would be remembered as the last of the samurai.
After the Sengoku Jidai, peace reigned for 200 years.
In Kyoto, the Emperor continued as divine head of state…
… but real power was held by the Tokugawa Shogunate.
For two centuries they ruled with absolute authority.
Japan prospered. The people were content.
In 1853, American warships changed everything.
The Shogun abandoned his people and signed the Treaty of Peace and Amity. The gates to Japan were open.
Trade was established, but the agreements favoured the western powers.
The economy faltered and the people suffered.
In 1863, the Emperor overruled the Shogun.
An Imperial decree ordered the expulsion of all western powers.
No longer would Japan be westernized. The time had come to strike back.
The western powers gave their answer.
The treacherous westerners brought death to our people.
The Shogun no longer commanded respect or loyalty. Imperial rule had to be restored.
To strengthen our position, the Emperor made peace with the British.
We will study their ways and discover their secrets. Only then can we destroy the Shogun and return honour to Japan.
The Emperor must be victorious.
After the Sengoku Jidai, peace reigned for 200 years.
In Kyoto, the Emperor continued as divine head of state…
… but real power was held by the Tokugawa Shogunate.
For two centuries they ruled with absolute authority.
Japan prospered. The people were content.
In 1854, American warships changed everything.
The Shogun welcomed the west and signed the Treaty of Peace and Amity. The gates to Japan were open.
Trade was established, but the agreements favoured the western powers.
The economy faltered and the people suffered.
In 1863, the Emperor overruled the Shogun.
An Imperial decree ordered the expulsion of all western powers.
Ten years of diplomacy, cast into the sea.
The western powers gave their answer.
The Emperor brought death to his people.
The Imperialists would pay for their misguided actions. Order had to be restored.
To strengthen our position, the Shogun allied with the French.
We will study their ways and discover their secrets. Only then can we destroy the fools around the Emperor and return honour to Japan.
The Shogun must be victorious.
Petals peel away, From the chrysanthemum throne. To reveal, nothing.
Everything given. In honours glorious name. Gone, lost forever.
The brave warrior. How will he be remembered? The poets decide.
Each clan has chosen their destiny.
We will serve the Emperor with strength and honour.
Friends will become enemies and enemies, friends, but these broken promises no longer concern us.
For there remains but two fates – those who find glory, and those who invite death and oblivion.
Imperial strength will be restored. The Emperor will be victorious.
Like crops in the sun, our people grow strong.
A new power has risen.
From this day we serve our own destiny.
No Shogun, no Emperor… we will rule Japan!
Each clan has chosen their destiny.
We will serve the Shogun with strength and honour.
Friends will become enemies and enemies, friends, but these broken promises no longer concern us.
For there remains but two fates – those who find glory, and those who invite death and oblivion.
Order will be restored. The Shogun will be victorious.
Victory is reserved for those who are willing to pay its price.
We have paid that price and now, we reap the rewards!
The time of the Shogun is over.
All hail the mighty Emperor!
Victory is reserved for those who are willing to pay its price.
We have paid that price and now, we reap the rewards!
We stand proud! The rulers of all Japan!
All hail our mighty leader!
Victory is reserved for those who are willing to pay its price.
We have paid that price and now, we reap the rewards!
The Emperor and his minions have been cast down!
All hail the mighty Shogun!
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
But we are master warriors too. Our archers are admired by all.
No arrow flies truer than a Chosokabe shaft.
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Chosokabe clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Chosokabe lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
This is our land. We respect its ways. Our farmers work hard, and grow more than other men.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
Our warriors are feared. Their skills with the no-dachi are unrivalled. In battle, they terrify the foe!
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Date clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Date lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
We do not walk the same path as other clans. We are revered as strong, independent, and brave in battle.
The Sengoku Jidai was a time of war. But those who say Japan has never seen the like have short memories. Long before the Ashikaga Shogunate, 400 years of peace were shattered by the Gempei War.
Amaterasu, the sun goddess, watched over the emperors of Japan and gave them power.
Their authority was absolute. An emperor could retire from the world and still have complete mastery over Japan.
But now, imperial might is crumbling, weakened by three noble families.
For many years, the Taira have secretly controlled the imperial court. Sophisticated, cunning, ruthless: they plot against any challengers to their hidden power.
The Minamoto are proud warriors. Their pleasure is battle: that, and the destruction of their enemies.
The Fujiwara were once the most powerful family in Japan, but now they only dream of power.
After years of careful planning the Taira are finally ready to make their move.
The Minamoto intend to block with all their might.
Meanwhile, the Fujiwara watch, and wait. Perhaps this moment is a chance to right wrongs...
The imperial peace is at an end. War is coming and blood will flow!
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
Strong walls: strong souls.
Our siege engines are equally mighty! Nothing stands before them!
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Hojo clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Hojo lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
Our castles are strong, the envy of Japan. We are rightly admired as master builders.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
The other clans fight.
But not all clans play by the same rules.
One embraces the darkness.
One embraces the shadows.
The Hattori are silent, deadly.
The Ashikaga Shogunate has much to fear.
Now is the time for the Hattori to reveal themselves and take their rightful place.
Fifteen forty-five. This is Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
Soon, the shogun in Kyoto himself will shake as he hears us approach!
Now the faithful will rise and claim their rightful dues! Our foes will fall, crushed by their own sins!
We wait no longer! Fate marches with us!
For 200 years the Ashikaga Shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become Shogun.
But who will win?
We Ikko Ikki are from every corner of Japan, united in one cause! We are the only true believers!
Our faith gives us power against any who oppose the will of heaven.
Our numbers swell as more flee from the great lords and their cruelty.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
The waves are unforgiving: Mori sailors have strength and great skill!
Skills passed down from father to son. They make us strong in war!
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Mori clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Mori lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
Others work the land. We are sea-masters, our ships the envy of all!
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
All know us, the commanders of a thousand spears. It is an honour to lead such men.
Our generals are battle-scarred veterans of righteous strength.
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Oda clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Oda lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
Others may covet titles, but ashigaru, common spearmen, are the bedrock of Oda might.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
It is in our blood, our traditions.
And in battle, our swordsmen are the envy of Japan. No blade is swifter, or more feared than ours.
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Shimazu clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Shimazu lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
We trace a line back to the first shogun, Yoritomo. Loyalty runs deep in the Shimazu.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
Let others march! We ride! We fly! Like storms in the mountains we thunder in battle!
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Takeda clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Takeda lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
To be Takeda is to be born in the saddle! We are master horsemen: our cavalry astound all!
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
But if words fail, in shadows, in silence: our ninja.
To know deception is to be on guard against its use. Few can hide from our metsuke.
We have Imagawa friends. Diplomacy does much. Our allegiance gives us security. But we must stand alone.
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Tokogawa clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Tokugawa lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
Our words have a power beyond the sword.
Fifteen forty-five. This is the Sengoku Jidai: the Age of the Country at War.
Our monks pray, but they also fight: and fight well!
But weapons alone do not win wars. Our merchants are cunning. Wealth buys many victories!
Bishamonten, the war god, has woken! Now is the time to defeat our enemies!
All will bow to the Uesugi clan. We wait no longer.
Destiny calls!
For 200 years the Ashikaga shoguns have ruled from Kyoto.
Great splendour and power were theirs.
Now the over-mighty clans no longer obey.
The time has come for a new warlord to become shogun.
But who will be victorious?
Uesugi lands have always provided for our people.
Our enemies are many and envious. They threaten our borders, and look for any weakness.
Faith is our strength, our wellspring. Let others be corrupted. We have the guidance of heaven!
The old gods have had their time.
Truth has come with the foreigners, and souls can be saved by following the Church’s teachings.
Heathens who cling to the old ways will be compelled by the power of Christ to kneel before God...
Strangers have come to our shores.
They bring weapons of smoke and fire, weapons that kill without honour, without skill.
But even so these foreigners and their guns could give a man power and victory. And victory wipes away dishonour.
Beauty and harmony, governed by one eternal law. All that begins must end, the reign of the old shogunate is over.
Like blossom on the breeze Will the wind carry my name? Who will remember?
Blood stains my hands: Not just my own, others too. Winter in my soul.
Everything fails, like the echoes of the Gionshoja bell.
Our time is over. The world forgets, and dreams of new conquerors.
The mighty are destroyed: fallen leaves on the wind.
I have sipped my last From the porcelain chawan: The rain storm blown out.
I dwelt in shadow. Forever running from light. Now, at last, I fall.
Tight around my neck The mailed fist of oppression: Cold as bitter winter.
I was restless water But I shall flow and crash no more. Now I shall be still.
Brave warriors, all: What will become of them now? A harvest gathered.
Red as autumn leaves I go to my ancestors. Will they welcome me?
Even now I hear them: Pounding hooves like spring thunder. My sword grows heavy.
Although I greet death I do not fear the icy grip. My soul, at peace, sleeps.
I do not fear death. Like the beautiful cherry tree, Life shall bloom again.
This ship carries a huge crew for boarding attacks. It is, however, hard to manoeuvre and vulnerable to enemy fire.
Ideal for whittling down the enemy before battle is joined; these troops are best kept at range and will suffer heavy losses if engaged in melee.
Boasting incredible killing range with their bows, these warrior monks are best used to pick off high-value enemies.
Powerful warriors, bow samurai can defend themselves in melee and fire burning arrows into the enemy!
Arrows as fleet as the wind; eyes as keen as the hawk.
These archers have devoted their lives to the mastery of the bow. No target lives long when their arrows take flight.
Fast moving, this small ship carries archers armed with deadly fire arrows capable of reducing enemy ships to dust.
This small, fast-moving ship is armed with cannon, but does not carry enough crew to ward off a boarding attempt.
Deadly and terrible these huge cannons cause significant damage to buildings when placed at range.
These mounted archers are capable of great turns of speed and can fire whilst mounted and on foot.
Versatility comes at a cost however; they are less accurate than foot archers and weak against spearmen.
The balled fist of the shogun, used to smash through enemy infantry and inspire fellow warriors.
Katana cavalry excel against enemy cavalry but are vulnerable to the spear and the bow.
Ideal for riding down fleeing enemies or driving off missile troops.
This fast light cavalry are vulnerable against well-trained infantry.
The men of the taisho are skilled in melee combat but vulnerable to spear and missile troops.
They are best reserved for the protection of the general, who increases the morale of nearby units.
Yari cavalry excel at chasing down a fleeing enemy but suffer heavy losses when confronted by spearmen or missile troops.
Raining fire upon the enemy has a devastating effect on their morale and the structural integrity of their buildings!
This small, fast-moving vessel can attack with exploding projectiles that can set fire to enemy ships.
This ship carries many archers, and can be used to board enemy vessels.
It is strong, but slow and can be sunk by cannon fire.
These swordsmen are the heart of your army, used primarily for melee attacks their main weaknesses are missile troops and cavalry.
Skilled swordsmen with excellent morale; these warriors are the body and soul of any army.
When man and sword are as one, mastery is meaningless.
The sword wields the man, and makes him unbeatable, a living legend.
Virtually undetectable on the battlefield this small group of highly trained ninjas can kill a man and be safely home before anyone even realises they were there!
Even the most heavily fortified castle is no match for these flaming balls! When kept at range these projectiles are incredibly effective.
These men are great at range and have a substantial effect on enemy morale but they must be withdrawn before engaging in melee or they will be massacred!
A line of matchlock armed warrior monks will strike fear into the heart of the enemy.
However, their lengthy reload times leave them vulnerable to cavalry charges.
More accurate than the ashigaru, matchlock samurai are capable of rank fire and possess excellent morale.
This swift ship carries musketeers to engage larger ships at range and will suffer heavy casualties if boarded.
With speed, manoeuvrability and strength this ship has many uses.
However, its versatility makes it less effective than more specialised ships.
These swordsmen are the heart of your army, used primarily for melee attacks their main weaknesses are missile troops and cavalry.
More powerful than the katana ashigaru, tachi samurai excel in melee combat and are vulnerable to cavalry and missile troops.
The men of the taisho are skilled in melee combat but vulnerable to spear and missile troops.
They are best reserved for the protection of the general, who increases the morale of nearby units.
Immovable as stone, naginata warrior monk cavalry are excellent against enemy cavalry but weak against spear and missile troops.
A life of reflection and dedication to their art has moulded these men into powerful warriors!
Only elite cavalry and missile troops are a match for them!
Armed with the deadly naginata these samurai are lethal to infantry and cavalry units but weak against missile troops.
A life of meditation and practice has made this hero into an unmatched expert with the deadly naginata. Few dare stand against his controlled fury!
The no-dachi requires great skill from its master; its size makes the bearer vulnerable in melee defence but on the charge, it is deadly!
This flagship of the fleet is under the command of a general.
It inspires nearby ships, but its size and slow speed make it an easy target for enemy cannons.
A large ocean going trade ship, the Red Seal increases trade income by opening trade possibilities in foreign lands.
With no fighting crew to speak of this ship should be kept out of battle at all costs.
Ideal as a long range siege weapon, these rockets are inaccurate but devastating should they reach their target.
Sengoku Bune are primarily used for chasing down smaller ships,
their sails make them much faster than other vessels of their size but a small crew leaves them vulnerable to boarding attacks.
This unarmed ship should be used solely for trade, if caught up in battle its best plan of attack is flight!
The raised tower on this vessel lets the crew rain arrows on enemy ships.
Boarding attacks by larger ships can be difficult to fight off.
Yari Ashigaru provide excellent defence against enemy cavalry charges but their tight formations leave them vulnerable to missile troops and skilled infantry units.
Unlike the yari ashigaru, yari samurai possess the ability to defend themselves in melee combat and are more effective against enemy cavalry.
Masters of defence, these men could hold against a charging horde of demons! Their defence is nigh impenetrable and enemy cavalry fall like leaves in a storm!
Their spear wall is nigh impenetrable and enemy cavalry fall like leaves in a storm!
With our conquest secured, the Chosokabe can take their rightful place alongside the other great clans.
Each clan has their own skills and challenges, but all strive toward the same goal.
All dream of a united Japan ruled by a single Shogun, their clan leader.
But who will triumph? Who has the power to unite Japan and end this age of total war?
Beautiful as cherry blossom and as deadly as the habu snake.
Much is hidden, and truth is seen too late as the blade slides home.
He who can see the shadows has power in the light.
Metsuke deal in bribery and corruption, keep order, and watch for assassins and spies.
A life of enlightenment is bliss, but to share this with the people is a greater gift.
Monks inspire armies and generals, and can inspire a repressed Buddhist population to rebel!
Where darkness meets the shadow, there dwells the ninja:
saboteurs and assassins, happy to do their lord’s bidding.
The Word of God is a great comfort to the people.
But it can also incite unrest, for not everyone has seen the light of Truth, and some may never believe.
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
We Chosokabe are triumphant!
From the northern mountains, to the depths of the southern seas, we rule! I rule!
The true master of Japan has been revealed. All men bow to me, their mighty shogun.
Our clan's greatness will be remembered. Its glory, its power…
...A legacy to last ten thousand years!
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
We Date are triumphant!
From the northern mountains, to the depths of the southern seas, we rule! I rule!
The true master of Japan has been revealed. All men bow to me, their mighty shogun.
Our clan's greatness will be remembered. Its glory, its power…
...A legacy to last ten thousand years!
Amaterasu rightly despaired of the Emperor.
Victory is ours! The blood of enemies has purified the land.
We will change Japan. Forever!
This is the time of the Shogun!
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
We Hojo are triumphant!
From the northern mountains, to the depths of the southern seas, we rule! I rule!
The true master of Japan has been revealed. All men bow to me, their mighty shogun.
Our clan's greatness will be remembered. Its glory, its power…
...A legacy to last ten thousand years!
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
We Hattori are triumphant!
From the northern mountains, to the depths of the southern seas, we rule! I rule!
The true master of Japan has been revealed. All men bow to me, their mighty shogun.
Our clan's greatness will be remembered. Its glory, its power…
...A legacy to last ten thousand years!
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
We Ikko - Ikki are triumphant!
From the northern mountains, to the depths of the southern seas, we rule! I rule!
The true master of Japan has been revealed. All men bow to me, their mighty shogun.
Our clan's greatness will be remembered. Its glory, its power…
...A legacy to last ten thousand years!
My ancestors would be proud. We drew the sword and went to war.
Our enemies are scattered! Their cities burn. All who opposed us are crushed! Their dead are silent.
